title: Can you guess where these Brooklyn drinking den resembling bars are?
text:
80 shares 7

If you thought there had been an influx of bearded men riding penny farthings, you'd be right.
Whether combing their handlebar moustaches, enjoying some edible nasturtiums in a pop-up cafe or carting a vintage gramophone along the streets of Brooklyn - it appears the hipster is here to stay.
And this breed of follically blessed youngster is not restricted to the streets of Williamsburg or London's trendy Dalston.
Scroll down for video
A. Beards, industrial lighting and a sharp-fringed staff member ... surely it must be Brooklyn?
In a recent article for Conde Naste Traveller magazine, Peter Jon Lindberg called this global spread of all things hipster the 'Brooklynization of the world'.
The gentrification of gritty, run-down areas has transformed many of the world's edgiest neighbourhoods into trendy destinations, and congregations for a community of 'like-minded' young people with alternative - yet alarmingly similar - tastes.

Petal power: Portuguese city is transformed by breathtaking... Share this article Share Here are a selection of 'Brooklynised' bars from around the globe. Your mission, should you chose to accept it, is to guess their locations. See below for answers.
B. Candle-lit chandelier, vintage signs and lots of grey. This edgy bar screams hipster. But where is it?
The former industrial districts of Williamsburg in New York and Dalston in East London have been firmly established as meccas for hipsters in recent years, thanks to an explosion of pop-up restaurants, vegan cafes, Bohemian shops, cutting-edge art galleries and gourmet coffee houses.
But similar establishments have sprung up in Riga, Latvia, Madrid's Malasana area and Florenten, in Tel Aviv.
Riga is the Capital of Culture 2014 and Skyscanner adds that Miera Iela is a ‘a swarm of art galleries, vintage shops, hairdresser-bookstores, restaurants and florists bartering green plants for herbal teas.’
C. This record shop and cafe is a regular haunt for beret wearers and man bun aficionados. But which city is it?
D. Tattoo sleeves? Check. American flag? Check. This bar would fit right in in Brooklyn, but where is it?
Miera Iela - or Peace Street - is home to a bohemian community of shopkeepers, publicans, gallery-owners, painters, writers and stylish layabouts who congregate at its unusual collection of inspired shops and cafés, such as DAD Cafe - a boutique coffee shop that offers home baking and regular acoustic concerts.
Malasana, in Madrid, is now hailed as the heart of Madrid’s counterculture scene, and has been likened to London’s Camden Town.
The Calle Espiritu Santo features two vintage shops, a florist, vegetable shop, five bars, three bohemian cafes, a retro food shop, two ethnic restaurants and two hip-hop clothing shops.
E. The likelihood that organic food is served at this grungy bar is quite high. Its location? You decide
F. Is that some kooky wallpaper we spy? And mismatched chairs? Can you guess this cool hipster city?
Meanwhile, in Amsterdam, the former industrial warehouses of Amsterdam-Noord have now been claimed by the ‘bearded urban explorers’, who use them as art galleries, skate parks, pop-up restaurants, and music festivals.
People also flock here to buy ‘upcycled’ furniture – old products re-sold as vintage items.
Sodermalm is now Stockholm’s version of Brooklyn with hoards of independent shops selling vintage jewellery, second-hand housewares and vinyl records; and Kallio in Helsinki, is Finland's answer to the trendy New York borough, with a large artist and student population and a buzzing open air market.
G. Retro cameras, tinned lager and wait, is that an ironic Hula surf board? Where was this cool snap taken?
H. Look at those books! Where is this hipster utopia and how can we get there?
Further afield in Fitzroy, Melbourne, which was once an industrial suburb full of social housing blocks, is Brunswick Street, lined vegan restaurants and retro pubs.
Norrebro, in Denmark, contains the most cycled upon street in Europe, and at the Laundromat Cafe, where you can go to do the laundry, use the Wi-Fi, eat cake, and drink coffee.
While the Florentin area of Tel Aviv, in Israel, is a small patch of warehouses, workshops, bakeries and bars which has gradually grown from working class suburb inhabited by Greek and Turkish immigrants to hipster paradise over past ten years.
Visitors can now do graffiti tours around the district, which often feature poems daubed on the walls.
I. It may be sparse but have you seen the wacky lighting? Where does this cool-looking bar belong?
BROOKLYN? OR HELSINKI? WHICH ONES DID YOU GET RIGHT? A. The Dad Cafe, in Riga, Latvia
B. The Distillery District, in Toronto
C. Multi Kulti Cafe and Record Shop, Sodermalm, Stockholm
D. The Sylvain bar, in New Orleans
E. Nanuchka, in the Florentin district, Tel Aviv
F. Lolina Vintage cafe in the Malasana district, Madrid
G. Bushwick Block Party, you guessed it, in Brooklyn
H. The Laundromat Cafe in Norrebro , Copenhagen, Denmark
I.The Naked for Satan Bar, Brunswick street, Melbourne
